repnme.cdata!:
Bolivia - Second Participatory Rural
            Investment Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Second
            Participatory Rural Investment Project for Bolivia is to
            pilot the consolidation of institutional arrangements
            between the national, prefecture and municipal governments
            and civil society for sustainable management of subnational
            public investment in selected productive sectors with an
            emphasis on territorial development. The restructuring will
            make four changes related to (i) safeguards (with the
            triggering of OP/BP 4.12, involuntary resettlement), (ii)
            new names for subnational government entities based on
            recent constitutional changes, (iii) a reallocation of loan
            proceeds to increase support provided under component one
            (institutional strengthening), and (iv) institutional
            support for the newly established autonomy state service.
            These changes are also reflected in the draft credit
            agreement and the addition of an involuntary resettlement framework.

repnme.cdata!:
Bolivia - Second Rural Investment Project :
            resettlement policy framework

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Second
            Participatory Rural Investment Project for Bolivia is to
            improve the economic opportunities of poor rural producers
            through productive investments generated in participatory
            planning processes at the community, municipal, and regional
            level. The project promotes and directs actions to
            strengthen the institutional framework for sub-national
            levels of government and to strengthen productive
            investments. More specifically, it will (a) facilitate
            participatory planning at the municipal and regional level,
            institutions; (b) promote the formation of municipal
            associations to create and implement territorial development
            strategies and achieve economies of scale in administering
            funds; (c) provide co-financing for investments in basic
            infrastructure and production support services; and (d)
            strengthen local public and civil society actors involved in
            defining and implementing territorial development
            strategies. The project may have differentiated impacts in
            that a portion of the soil can have diverse effects
            depending on the characteristics of the site especially
            depending on the relative abundance or scarcity of land. In
            areas of smallholdings, the immobilization of agricultural
            land certainly has greater impact in areas of large estates.
            For example, a subproject that includes the involvement of a
            small farm in an area that exceeds 5 percent would be very
            damaging and should be seriously considered for exclusion.
